DataElement.preferredName: Breast DCIS Histologic Subtype Classification Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The histologic subtype of a breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._A group forming a type within a larger type._A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Property.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:Subtype; a group forming a type within a larger type.:Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
A group forming a type within a larger type.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: MCL:Molecular and Cellular Characterization of Screened Lesions
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 3/8/22 jk released as part of quarterly content review and prior reviews with SMEs.  5-30-19 tt created for Breast initial diagnosis module.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  It is also known as DCIS.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities._A group forming a type within a larger type._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Data from an original source is not present, accessible or ready for use or service.

Concepts.definition: Data from an original source is not present, accessible or ready for use or service.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-invasive breast adenocarcinoma located in a distended duct. It is characterized by the presence of papillary structures with fibrovascular stalks. In the absence of ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive carcinoma in adjacent tissues, the prognosis is usually favorable.

Concepts.longName: Breast Papillary Ductal Carcinoma In Situ
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of filiform arborizing fibrovascular cores lined by neoplastic ductal epithelium. (WHO 2019)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An intraductal papillary carcinoma in which the neoplastic epithelial cells are arranged in micropapillary patterns.

Concepts.longName: Breast Micropapillary Ductal Carcinoma In Situ
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of neoplastic epithelial cells arranged in micropapillary patterns.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast characterized by the presence of a cribriform architectural pattern.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Cribriform Pattern
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of a cribriform architectural pattern.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ, Solid Type

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ, Solid Type
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast in which the tumor cells fill the ductal spaces as solid sheets.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Solid Type
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ in which the tumor cells fill the ductal spaces as solid sheets.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: High Grade Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ

ValueMeaning.preferredName: High Grade Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells with severe dysplasia and the formation of micropapillary, cribriform, or solid patterns. The nuclei show marked pleomorphism and have prominent nucleoli. Mitotic activity is usually present. There is comedo-type of necrosis present in the ducts. The necrotic debris is surrounded by pleomorphic malignant cells.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, High Grade
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells with severe dysplasia and the formation of micropapillary, cribriform, or solid patterns. The nuclei show marked pleomorphism and have prominent nucleoli. Mitotic activity is usually present. There is comedo-type of necrosis present in the ducts. The necrotic debris is surrounded by pleomorphic malignant cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant sweat gland neoplasm with apocrine differentiation. Representative examples include apocrine adenoma, ceruminous adenocarcinoma, and apocrine breast carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant sweat gland neoplasm with apocrine differentiation. Representative examples include apocrine adenoma, ceruminous adenocarcinoma, and apocrine breast carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by a papillary growth pattern. A papillary carcinoma may be composed of glandular cells (papillary adenocarcinoma), squamous cells (papillary squamous cell carcinoma), or transitional cells (papillary transitional cell carcinoma). Bladder carcinoma is a representative example of papillary transitional cell carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm characterized by a papillary growth pattern. A papillary carcinoma may be composed of glandular cells (papillary adenocarcinoma), squamous cells (papillary squamous cell carcinoma), or transitional cells (papillary transitional cell carcinoma). Bladder carcinoma is a representative example of papillary transitional cell carcinoma.

In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.:A group forming a type within a larger type.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
